title: Latest News from Science Magazine
description: Keyword search result for Alerts: News Weekly Headlines -- New results matching your keyword search query (updated daily).

items.title: Traces of ancient seafloor cataclysms turn up in the Himalayas
items.description: Vast undersea eruptions may be undercounted source of extinctions through Earth’s history

items.title: Trump slump? Attendance plummets at some science meetings, but others hold steady
items.description: Amid travel bans, a government shutdown, and funding crunches, 2025 was a turbulent year for U.S. scientific societies

items.title: U.K. physics community braces for deep funding cuts
items.description: Research council to slash funding for particle physics, nuclear physics, and astronomy by 30%, prompting alarm across the research community

items.title: As humans return to the Moon, scientists confront the dangers of deep-space radiation
items.description: Shields and biological countermeasures could help protect astronauts during prolonged missions beyond Earth's magnetic bubble

items.title: Snakes on a train? Deadly reptiles may be hopping railcars in India
items.description: Trains may be transporting cobras and other venomous snakes to new parts of the country

items.title: In a twist, polar bears are getting fatter in the Norwegian Arctic
items.description: With sea ice dwindling, the massive predators are relying more on land-based food sources such as reindeer

items.title: Earth-size planet spotted with yearlong orbit
items.description: Long-overlooked Kepler signal discovered by citizen scientists reveals promising world worth a closer look

items.title: A motley crew of fossils illuminates an ancient, mysterious extinction event
items.description: 512-million-year-old marine fossils highlight life and death at the Cambrian explosion’s close

items.title: Splat! Could roadkill replace some studies of live animals?
items.description: <cite>Science</cite> chats with an ecologist about the advantages of using discarded carcasses for research

items.title: Fluttering ‘tails’ on bird nests confuse would-be predators
items.description: Blue manakins in Brazil use “disruptive camouflage” to protect their eggs, new study finds
